text:
angelito [2:53 PM]  
assuming that a particular chaincode must be completely public, can you think about an efficient way to retrieve the code which is actually deployed? I mean, not everyone could have the *.java files but would need to know what they are invoking...
<@U10V341PH>  - why not just store the chaincode in github?
of course technically the code package is actually in the deployment transaction on the ledger as well.
thanks <@U0PB67X4K> github is an idea. Actually, I was looking for a way to extract the code package from the ledger, I think it will not be in readable text, right?
<@U10V341PH> the code package is written into  tar file and saved in ledger.
Thank you <@U1VG8LNP3> . Is it possible to read the tar
file and do you know if it contains the *.java or *.go text?

I had a question on decrypting transaction payload when confidentiality is true.
In sdk I have seen that for every transaction a TxKey is been generated to generate the transaction payload and each TxKey has a private key hex and public key hex.
Now in order to decrypt any transaction payload in the furture do I have to keep track of the private key hex along with transaction id?
Or is the txKey linked to invokers Ecert/Tcert, such that Ecert/Tcert private key can be used to decrypt the payload?

<@U10V341PH> the tar was saved in the deploy transaction.  For go, the tar file contains all the files in GOPATH. You can read the deploy transaction in ledger and extract all the .go file. I think java is similar.
